While the average accuracy remains similar, the variance of the final accuracy distribution decreases significantly. We provide full results of other uniformity measurements (including variance) in Table 5, Appendix E.1, and show that qğ‘q-FFL encourages more uniform distributions under all metrics.

In our first experiments, we verify that the proposed objective qğ‘q-FFL leads to more fair solutions (DefinitionÂ 1) for federated data. In Figure 2, we compare the final testing accuracy distributions of two objectives (q=0ğ‘0q=0 and a tuned value of q>0ğ‘0q>0) averaged across 5 random shuffles of each dataset. We observe that while the average testing accuracy remains fairly consistent, the objectives with q>0ğ‘0q>0 result in more centered (i.e., fair) testing accuracy distributions with lower variance. In particular, while maintaining roughly the same average accuracy, qğ‘q-FFL reduces the variance of accuracies across all devices by 45% on average.
We further report the worst and best 10% testing accuracies and the variance of the final accuracy distributions in Table 1. Comparing q=0ğ‘0q=0 and q>0ğ‘0q>0, we see that the average testing accuracy remains almost unchanged with the proposed objective despite significant reductions in variance. We report full results on all uniformity measurements (including variance) in TableÂ 5 in the appendix, and show that qğ‘q-FFL encourages more uniform accuracies under other metrics as well. We observe similar results on training accuracy distributions in Figure 6 and Table 6, Appendix E. In TableÂ 1, the average accuracy is with respect to all data points, not all devices; however, we observe similar results with respect to devices, as shown in Table 7, Appendix E.

Choosing qğ‘q. As discussed in SectionÂ 3.3, a natural question is to determine how qğ‘q should be tuned in the qğ‘q-FFL objective. Our framework is flexible in that it allows one to choose qğ‘q to tradeoff between fairness/uniformity and average accuracy. We empirically show that there are a family of qğ‘qâ€™s that can result in variable levels of fairness (and accuracy) on synthetic data in Table 11, Appendix E.
In general, this value can be tuned based on the data/application at hand and the desired amount of fairness. Another reasonable approach in practice would be to run Algorithm 2 with multiple qğ‘qâ€™s in parallel to obtain multiple final global models, and then select amongst these based on performance (e.g., accuracy) on the validation data.
Rather than using just one optimal qğ‘q for all devices, for example, each device could pick a device-specific model based on their validation data. We show additional performance improvements with this device-specific strategy in Table 12 in Appendix E. Finally, we note that one potential issue is that increasing the value of qğ‘q may slow the speed of convergence. However, for values of qğ‘q that result in more fair results on our datasets, we do not observe significant decrease in the convergence speed, as shown in Figure 8, Appendix E.

In this section, we show the efficiency of our proposed distributed solver, qğ‘q-FedAvg, by comparing Algorithm 2 with its non-local-updating baseline qğ‘q-FedSGD (Algorithm 1) to solve the same objective (same q>0ğ‘0q>0 as in Table 1). At each communication round, we have each method perform the same amount of computation, with qğ‘q-FedAvg running one epoch of local updates on each selected device while qğ‘q-FedSGD runs gradient descent with the local training data. In FigureÂ 4, qğ‘q-FedAvg converges faster than qğ‘q-FedSGD in terms of communication rounds in most cases due to its local updating scheme. The slower convergence of qğ‘q-FedAvg compared with qğ‘q-FedSGD on the synthetic dataset may be due to the fact that when local data distributions are highly heterogeneous, local updating schemes may allow local models to move too far away from the initial global model, potentially hurting convergence; see Figure 10 in Appendix E for more details.
We demonstrate the fairness of qğ‘q-FFL in TableÂ 1 in terms of variance. Here, we report similar results in terms of other uniformity measures (the last two columns).

In Section 4.2, we show that qğ‘q-FFL leads to more fair accuracy distributions while maintaining approximately the same testing accuracies. Note that we report average testing accuracy with respect to all data points in Table 1. However, we observe similar results on average accuracy with respect to all devices between q=0ğ‘0q=0 and q>0ğ‘0q>0 objectives, as shown in Table 7. This indicates that qğ‘q-FFL can reduce the variance of the accuracy distribution without sacrificing the average accuracy over devices or over data points.

Effects of data heterogeneity and the number of devices on unfairness. To study how data heterogeneity and the total number of devices affect unfairness in a more direct way, we investigate into a set of synthetic datasets where we can quantify the degree of heterogeneity. The results are shown in TableÂ 10 below. We generate three synthetic datasets following the process described in AppendixÂ D.1, but with different parameters to control heterogeneity. In particular, we generate an IID dataâ€” Synthetic (IID) by setting the same Wğ‘ŠW and bğ‘b on all devices and setting the samples xkâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,1)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ’©01x_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1) for any device kğ‘˜k. We instantiate two non-identically distributed datasets (Synthetic (1, 1) and Synthetic (2, 2)) from Synthetic (Î±ğ›¼\alpha, Î²ğ›½\beta) where ukâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Î±)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜ğ’©0ğ›¼u_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\alpha) and Bkâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Î²)similar-tosubscriptğµğ‘˜ğ’©0ğ›½B_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\beta). Recall that Î±,Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha,\beta allows to precisely manipulate the degree of heterogeneity with larger Î±,Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha,\beta values indicating more statistical heterogeneity. Therefore, from top to bottom in TableÂ 10, data are more heterogeneous. For each dataset, we further create two variants with different number of participating devices. We see that as data become more heterogeneous and as the number of devices in the network increases, the accuracy distribution tends to be less uniform.

In Table 11, we show the accuracy distribution statistics of using a family of qğ‘qâ€™s on synthetic data. Our objective and methods are not sensitive to any particular qğ‘q since all q>0ğ‘0q>0 values can lead to more fair solutions compared with q=0ğ‘0q=0. In our experiments in Section 4, we report the results using the qğ‘q values selected following the protocol described in Appendix D.2.3.

In these experiments, we explore a device-specific strategy for selecting qğ‘q in qğ‘q-FFL. We solve qğ‘q-FFL with qâˆˆ{0,0.001,0.01,0.1,1,2,5,10}ğ‘00.0010.010.112510q\in\{0,0.001,0.01,0.1,1,2,5,10\} in parallel. After training, each device selects the best resulting model based on the validation data and tests the performance of the model using the testing set. We report the results in terms of testing accuracy in Table 12. Interestingly, using this device-specific strategy the average accuracy in fact increases while the variance of accuracies is reduced, in comparison with q=0ğ‘0q=0. We note that this strategy does induce more local computation and additional communication load at each round. However, it does not increase the number of communication rounds if run in parallel.

Weighting devices adversarially. We further compare with AFLÂ (Mohri etÂ al., 2019), which is the only work we are aware of that aims to address fairness issues in federated learning. We implement a non-stochastic version of AFL where all devices are selected and updated each round, and perform grid search on the AFL hyperparameters, Î³wsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘¤\gamma_{w} and Î³Î»subscriptğ›¾ğœ†\gamma_{\lambda}. In order to devise a setup that is as favorable to AFL as possible, we modify Algorithm 2 by sampling all devices and letting each of them run gradient descent at each round. We use the same small datasets (AdultÂ (Blake, 1998) and subsampled Fashion MNISTÂ (Xiao etÂ al., 2017))
and the same logistic regression model as inÂ Mohri etÂ al. (2019). Full details of the implementation and hyperparameters (e.g., values of q1subscriptğ‘1q_{1} and q2subscriptğ‘2q_{2}) are provided in AppendixÂ D.2.3. We note that, as opposed to AFL, qğ‘q-FFL is flexible depending on the amount of fairness desired, with larger qğ‘q leading to more accuracy uniformity.
As discussed, qğ‘q-FFL generalizes AFL in this regard, as AFL is equivalent to qğ‘q-FFL with a large enough qğ‘q.
In Table 2, we observe that qğ‘q-FFL can in fact achieve higher testing accuracy than AFL on the device with the worst performance (i.e., the problem that the AFL was designed to solve) with appropriate qğ‘q. This also indicates that qğ‘q-FFL obtains the most fair solutions in certain cases. We also observe that qğ‘q-FFL converges faster in terms of communication rounds compared with AFL to obtain similar performance (AppendixÂ E), which we speculate is due to the non-smoothness of the AFL objective.

Note that in federated learning, we are dealing with costs and not utilities. Thus, max-min in resource allocation corresponds to min-max in our setting.
With this analogy, it is clear that in our proposed objective qğ‘q-FFL (2), the case where q=+âˆğ‘q=+\infty corresponds to min-max fairness since it is optimizing for the worst-performing device, similar to what was proposed inÂ Mohri etÂ al. (2019). Also, q=0ğ‘0q=0 corresponds to zero fairness, which reduces to the original FedAvg objective (1). In resource allocation problems, Î±ğ›¼\alpha can be tuned for trade-offs between fairness and system efficiency. In federated settings, qğ‘q can be tuned based on the desired level of fairness (e.g., desired variance of accuracy distributions) and other performance metrics such as the overall accuracy. For instance, in Table 2 in Section 4.3, we demonstrate on two datasets that as qğ‘q increases, the overall average accuracy decreases slightly while the worst accuracies are increased significantly and the variance of the accuracy distribution decreases.

In comparing qğ‘q-FedAvgâ€™s efficiency with qğ‘q-FedSGD, we also tune a best learning rate for qğ‘q-FedSGD methods on q=0ğ‘0q=0. For each comparison, we fix devices selected and mini-batch orders across all runs. We stop training when the training loss Fâ€‹(w)ğ¹ğ‘¤F(w) does not decrease for 10 rounds. When running AFL methods, we search for a best Î³wsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘¤\gamma_{w} and Î³Î»subscriptğ›¾ğœ†\gamma_{\lambda} such that AFL achieves the highest testing accuracy on the device with the highest loss within a fixed number of rounds. For Adult, we use Î³w=0.1subscriptğ›¾ğ‘¤0.1\gamma_{w}=0.1 and Î³Î»=0.1subscriptğ›¾ğœ†0.1\gamma_{\lambda}=0.1; for Fashion MNIST, we use Î³w=0.001subscriptğ›¾ğ‘¤0.001\gamma_{w}=0.001 and Î³Î»=0.01subscriptğ›¾ğœ†0.01\gamma_{\lambda}=0.01. We use the same Î³wsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘¤\gamma_{w} as step-sizes for qğ‘q-FedAvg on Adult and Fashion MNIST. In Table 2, q1=0.01,q2=2formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘10.01subscriptğ‘22q_{1}=0.01,q_{2}=2 for qğ‘q-FFL on Adult and q1=5,q2=15formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘15subscriptğ‘215q_{1}=5,q_{2}=15 for qğ‘q-FFL on Fashion MNIST. Similarly, the number of local epochs is fixed to 1 whenever we perform local updates.

S4.T3.caption: Table 3: Statistics of the accuracy distribution of personalized models using qğ‘q-MAML. The method with q=0ğ‘0q=0 corresponds to MAML. Similarly, we see that the variance is reduced while the accuracy of the worst 10% devices is increased.
references:
To achieve this goal, we propose a new method, qğ‘q-MAML, by combining qğ‘q-FFL with the popular meta-learning method MAMLÂ (Finn etÂ al., 2017). In particular, instead of updating the global model in the way described in MAML, we update the global parameters using the gradients of the qğ‘q-FFL objective 1q+1â€‹Fkq+1â€‹(w)1ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘1ğ‘¤\frac{1}{q+1}F_{k}^{q+1}(w), with weights inferred from LemmaÂ 3. Similarly, qğ‘q-MAML with q=0ğ‘0q=0 reduces to MAML, and qğ‘q-MAML with qâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘q\to\infty corresponds to MAML with a most â€˜fairâ€™ initialization and a potentially lower average accuracy. The detailed algorithm is summarized in AlgorithmÂ 4 in AppendixÂ C.2. We sample 10 tasks at each round during meta-training, and train for 5 iterations of (mini-batch) SGD for personalization on meta-testing tasks. We report test accuracy of personalized models on the meta-testing tasks.
From Figure 5 and Table 3 above, we observe that qğ‘q-MAML is able to learn initializations which result in fairer personalized models with lower variance.

In our first experiments, we verify that the proposed objective qğ‘q-FFL leads to more fair solutions (DefinitionÂ 1) for federated data. In Figure 2, we compare the final testing accuracy distributions of two objectives (q=0ğ‘0q=0 and a tuned value of q>0ğ‘0q>0) averaged across 5 random shuffles of each dataset. We observe that while the average testing accuracy remains fairly consistent, the objectives with q>0ğ‘0q>0 result in more centered (i.e., fair) testing accuracy distributions with lower variance. In particular, while maintaining roughly the same average accuracy, qğ‘q-FFL reduces the variance of accuracies across all devices by 45% on average.
We further report the worst and best 10% testing accuracies and the variance of the final accuracy distributions in Table 1. Comparing q=0ğ‘0q=0 and q>0ğ‘0q>0, we see that the average testing accuracy remains almost unchanged with the proposed objective despite significant reductions in variance. We report full results on all uniformity measurements (including variance) in TableÂ 5 in the appendix, and show that qğ‘q-FFL encourages more uniform accuracies under other metrics as well. We observe similar results on training accuracy distributions in Figure 6 and Table 6, Appendix E. In TableÂ 1, the average accuracy is with respect to all data points, not all devices; however, we observe similar results with respect to devices, as shown in Table 7, Appendix E.

In Section 4.2, we show that qğ‘q-FFL leads to more fair accuracy distributions while maintaining approximately the same testing accuracies. Note that we report average testing accuracy with respect to all data points in Table 1. However, we observe similar results on average accuracy with respect to all devices between q=0ğ‘0q=0 and q>0ğ‘0q>0 objectives, as shown in Table 7. This indicates that qğ‘q-FFL can reduce the variance of the accuracy distribution without sacrificing the average accuracy over devices or over data points.

Weighting devices equally. We compare qğ‘q-FFL with uniform sampling schemes and report testing accuracy in Figure 3. A table with the final accuracies and three fairness metrics is given in the appendix in TableÂ 9. While the â€˜weighting each device equallyâ€™ heuristic tends to outperform our method in training accuracy distributions (Figure 7 and Table 8 in Appendix E), we see that our method produces more fair solutions in terms of testing accuracies. One explanation for this is that uniform sampling is a static method and can easily overfit to devices with very few data points, whereas
qğ‘q-FFL will put less weight on a device once its loss becomes small, potentially providing better generalization performance due to its dynamic nature.

In Figure 7 and Table 8, we show that in terms of training accuracies, the uniform sampling heuristic may outperform qğ‘q-FFL (as opposed to the testing accuracy results in SectionÂ 4). We suspect that this is because the uniform sampling baseline is a static method and is likely to overfit to those devices with few samples. In additional to Figure 3 in SectionÂ 4.3, we also report the average testing accuracy with respect to data points, best 10%, worst 10% accuracies, and the variance (along with two other uniformity measures) in Table 9.

A5.T9.caption: Table 9: More statistics showing more fair solutions induced by qğ‘q-FFL compared with the uniform sampling baseline in terms of test accuracies. Again, we observe that under qğ‘q-FFL, the testing accuracy of the worst 10% devices tends to increase compared with uniform sampling, and the variance of the final testing accuracies is smaller. Similarly, qğ‘q-FFL is also more fair than uniform sampling in terms of other uniformity metrics.

references: Effects of data heterogeneity and the number of devices on unfairness. To study how data heterogeneity and the total number of devices affect unfairness in a more direct way, we investigate into a set of synthetic datasets where we can quantify the degree of heterogeneity. The results are shown in TableÂ 10 below. We generate three synthetic datasets following the process described in AppendixÂ D.1, but with different parameters to control heterogeneity. In particular, we generate an IID dataâ€” Synthetic (IID) by setting the same Wğ‘ŠW and bğ‘b on all devices and setting the samples xkâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,1)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ’©01x_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1) for any device kğ‘˜k. We instantiate two non-identically distributed datasets (Synthetic (1, 1) and Synthetic (2, 2)) from Synthetic (Î±ğ›¼\alpha, Î²ğ›½\beta) where ukâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Î±)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜ğ’©0ğ›¼u_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\alpha) and Bkâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Î²)similar-tosubscriptğµğ‘˜ğ’©0ğ›½B_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\beta). Recall that Î±,Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha,\beta allows to precisely manipulate the degree of heterogeneity with larger Î±,Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha,\beta values indicating more statistical heterogeneity. Therefore, from top to bottom in TableÂ 10, data are more heterogeneous. For each dataset, we further create two variants with different number of participating devices. We see that as data become more heterogeneous and as the number of devices in the network increases, the accuracy distribution tends to be less uniform.

A larger qğ‘q results in more fairness (smaller variance), but potentially lower accuracy. Similarly, a larger qğ‘q imposes more uniformity in terms of other metricsâ€”(a) the cosine similarity/angle between the accuracy distribution and the all-ones vector 1, and (b) the KL divergence between the normalized accuracy ğ’‚ğ’‚{\bm{a}} and a uniform distribution ğ’–ğ’–{\bm{u}}.

Choosing qğ‘q. As discussed in SectionÂ 3.3, a natural question is to determine how qğ‘q should be tuned in the qğ‘q-FFL objective. Our framework is flexible in that it allows one to choose qğ‘q to tradeoff between fairness/uniformity and average accuracy. We empirically show that there are a family of qğ‘qâ€™s that can result in variable levels of fairness (and accuracy) on synthetic data in Table 11, Appendix E.
In general, this value can be tuned based on the data/application at hand and the desired amount of fairness. Another reasonable approach in practice would be to run Algorithm 2 with multiple qğ‘qâ€™s in parallel to obtain multiple final global models, and then select amongst these based on performance (e.g., accuracy) on the validation data.
Rather than using just one optimal qğ‘q for all devices, for example, each device could pick a device-specific model based on their validation data. We show additional performance improvements with this device-specific strategy in Table 12 in Appendix E. Finally, we note that one potential issue is that increasing the value of qğ‘q may slow the speed of convergence. However, for values of qğ‘q that result in more fair results on our datasets, we do not observe significant decrease in the convergence speed, as shown in Figure 8, Appendix E.

In Table 11, we show the accuracy distribution statistics of using a family of qğ‘qâ€™s on synthetic data. Our objective and methods are not sensitive to any particular qğ‘q since all q>0ğ‘0q>0 values can lead to more fair solutions compared with q=0ğ‘0q=0. In our experiments in Section 4, we report the results using the qğ‘q values selected following the protocol described in Appendix D.2.3.

A5.T12.caption: Table 12: Effects of running qğ‘q-FFL with several qğ‘qâ€™s in parallel. We train multiple global models (corresponding to different qğ‘qâ€™s) independently in the network. After the training finishes, each device picks up a best, device-specific model based on the performance (accuracy) on the validation data. While this adds additional local computation and more communication load per round, the device-specific strategy has the added benefit of increasing the accuracies of devices with the worst 10% accuracies and devices with the best 10% accuracies simultaneously. This strategy is built upon the proposed primitive Algorithm 2, and in practice, people can develop other heuristics to improve the performance (similar to what we explore here), based on the method of adaptively averaging model updates proposed in Algorithm 2.

Choosing qğ‘q. As discussed in SectionÂ 3.3, a natural question is to determine how qğ‘q should be tuned in the qğ‘q-FFL objective. Our framework is flexible in that it allows one to choose qğ‘q to tradeoff between fairness/uniformity and average accuracy. We empirically show that there are a family of qğ‘qâ€™s that can result in variable levels of fairness (and accuracy) on synthetic data in Table 11, Appendix E.
In general, this value can be tuned based on the data/application at hand and the desired amount of fairness. Another reasonable approach in practice would be to run Algorithm 2 with multiple qğ‘qâ€™s in parallel to obtain multiple final global models, and then select amongst these based on performance (e.g., accuracy) on the validation data.
Rather than using just one optimal qğ‘q for all devices, for example, each device could pick a device-specific model based on their validation data. We show additional performance improvements with this device-specific strategy in Table 12 in Appendix E. Finally, we note that one potential issue is that increasing the value of qğ‘q may slow the speed of convergence. However, for values of qğ‘q that result in more fair results on our datasets, we do not observe significant decrease in the convergence speed, as shown in Figure 8, Appendix E.

In these experiments, we explore a device-specific strategy for selecting qğ‘q in qğ‘q-FFL. We solve qğ‘q-FFL with qâˆˆ{0,0.001,0.01,0.1,1,2,5,10}ğ‘00.0010.010.112510q\in\{0,0.001,0.01,0.1,1,2,5,10\} in parallel. After training, each device selects the best resulting model based on the validation data and tests the performance of the model using the testing set. We report the results in terms of testing accuracy in Table 12. Interestingly, using this device-specific strategy the average accuracy in fact increases while the variance of accuracies is reduced, in comparison with q=0ğ‘0q=0. We note that this strategy does induce more local computation and additional communication load at each round. However, it does not increase the number of communication rounds if run in parallel.
